intro: Loranthus warmingii, commonly known as the Chinese mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees, primarily in the family Rutaceae. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while still performing some photosynthesis using modified leaves. The plant produces small, white or yellowish flowers, followed by fleshy, red berries that contain seeds. It is native to China and is often found growing on species such as citrus and Elaeocarpaceae. Due to its parasitic nature and unique ecological role, it plays an important part in the biodiversity of its native forest ecosystems.
